prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: The proposed observations require only continuum measurements at 230 GHz as the goal is to probe the underlying accretion luminosity of the embedded sources. We desire well calibrated measurements of the continuum flux at Band 6, using the pre-defined optimal continuum parameters for Band 6 as provided in the ALMA Technical Handbook.

The distance to Serpens has been recently reclassified to be ~400 pc (Dzib et al. 2010) and thus 0.3" angular scales relate to ~120 AU linear dimensions. Models of deeply embedded protostars show that the envelope's 'effective photosphere', the location where the absorbed stellar and accretion luminosity is reprocessed to long enough wavelengths to escape the outer envelope is on the order of 100 AU (Johnstone et al. 2013). Thus, this is the best scale to watch for variation in the bolometric luminosity of these objects.
The requested largest angular scale of 3" (~1200 AU) allows us to carefully model the inner envelope and compare directly with the CARMA observations (Enoch et al. 2011). The CARMA observations reveal that all of our sources in Serpens have structure across these angular scales.

All but three of the twelve sources to be observed have 1" resolution peak flux density measurements from CARMA (Enoch et al. 2011). The peak flux measurements listed in this proposal assume that the emission is NO MORE compact than found by CARMA. Given that we desire 0.3" (~120 AU) resolution with ALMA, the peak fluxes have been scaled down by the ratio of the beam areas, ~10. The quoted values are thus lower limits on the signal and S/N that will be achieved. If the CARMA flux remains unresolved in the sythesized ALMA beam, the signal and S/N will be 10 times higher than predicted here.
As we are planning to use these observations as a first epoch in a long-term monitoring campaign, our goal is to achieve excellent calibration and high signal to noise, S/N > 50. The CARMA results show that this is achievable for all sources using a 1" beam. Our expectation, however, is that the source peaks will be more compact than 1" - as these are known deeply embedded protostars - and thus a majority of the sources will attain the desired S/N on angular scales approaching 0.3".

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract:
Low-mass stars form via gravitational collapse of molecular cloud cores. The evolution of the mass accretion onto a forming protostar depends on the rate at which the interior of the core collapses, the significance of a circumstellar disk as a temporary mass reservoir and transportation mechanism, and the physics of how the inner disk accretes. Despite a clear requirement for time dependency in the accretion rate onto deeply embedded protostars and a large number of theoretical mechanisms for powering variability, our understanding of both the timescale and amplitude of variability is almost entirely unconstrained.
We propose to use ALMA to observe twelve deeply embedded protostars in Serpens in continuum at 230 GHz in order to (a) compare against 2010 epoch CARMA observations to uncover rare large-amplitude accretion variation and (b) provide well-calibrated first-epoch brightness measurements for future comparison as part of a continuing campaign dedicated to uncovering the observational signature of episodic accretion. These observations are vital for discriminating between the various theoretical models of episodic accretion onto deeply embedded protostars.
